summary:
WAIT 
what if instead of Cyrus just seeing tj and Kira and either confronting or just walking away
He goes to swing on HIS...
body:
WAIT

what if instead of Cyrus just seeing tj and Kira and either confronting or just walking away

He goes to swing on HIS swing, ignoring the two of them and acting unbothered,

And tj is the one who can’t bare it, and approaches Cyrus with an apology

Idk just a thought

summary: Unpopular opinion: I love angst. It's gonna suck so much to see TJ and Kira hanging out, on the swings of all places, and having...
question: Unpopular opinion: I love angst. It's gonna suck so much to see TJ and Kira hanging out, on the swings of all places, and having fun, or in TJ's case, pretending to have fun. But damn the apology scene and  Tyrus feels we're gonna get when all this is over will be WORTH IT. The pain will make the future happiness so much sweeter.
answer: true. i love angst in hindsight but not now lol

reblog.comment: true. i love angst in hindsight but not now lol

summary: Anytime i talk to a anti Jyrus tyrus shipper they all say the same thing
body:
Anytime i talk to a anti Jyrus tyrus shipper they all say the same thing

“Jonah called Cyrus helpless”

What They think Jonah said “ugh Cyrus is so helpless and stupid i hate him”

What Jonah said is “i forget how helpless he can be” this means he doesnt see Cyrus as helpless .

blog.name: mackmeta
blog.title: Meta, Analysis, and Speculation
blog.description: I'm Dave (he/him). I'm a fan of Andi Mack, Riverdale, and Girl Meets World, and other shows and movies. Feel free to send me asks!

summary: did you see that someone has been added as a "birthday party guest" in a moving day on imdb? do you think that confirms that the...
question: did you see that someone has been added as a "birthday party guest" in a moving day on imdb? do you think that confirms that the event in the snow is someone's birthday?
answer:
Yes I have. It’s very unlikely the gang is at the gazebo itself for a birthday party as there were no signs of any guests or chairs or benches or birthday decorations of any kind during the original filming of A Moving Day or in the re-shoots. But I could see there being a birthday party beforehand and I do find it interesting that this credit was only added very recently as this same extra had added his role as man walking in the park in Unloading Zone almost immediately after it was filmed in October. 

If this credit is legit and it is for A Moving Day the most likely option would be for Bex’s birthday since we’ve seen Andi and Bowie’s and Celia’s birthdays already. in the original production the only recurring character was Ham and while they re-shot most of the Mack family scenes on the way to and at the Gazebo there were other scenes that likely had to be scrapped so in theory there would probably be room for Bex to have a birthday party. And either way they need to get the Macks out to the Gazebo so maybe they go there and Andi thinks it’s part of Bex’s birthday gift but it turns out to be Jonah singing You Girl to her.

That being said, imdb is a bit of a mess right now so we should take new credits with a grain of salt. For some reason someone removed the casting for the finale and replaced it with the cast list for the original 3x18 which was filmed at Snuck Farm. That’s why Luke, Raquel, and Anson aren’t currently listed for the series finale and some middle aged women who were likely wedding guests or wedding planners in the original 3x18 are listed as appearing in the finale even though all their scenes were cut.

summary: Of course we will have to wait and see, but in your opinion. Do you think Kira's redemption arc will be seeded in 3x15 and...
question: Of course we will have to wait and see, but in your opinion. Do you think Kira's redemption arc will be seeded in 3x15 and continue over the remaining episodes that she is in? Or do you think a character like herself, can be redeem within a few minutes of a singular episode?
answer:
I really don’t know, and I haven’t put too much thought into Kira’s arc honestly, so this post might just be me rambling while I figure out my own thoughts on the matter. For some people, she will not be fully redeemed no matter what happens on the show. She came in swinging, and this show’s audience aren’t just going to let that go no matter how complex the redemption is. 

I’ve said all along that I think that Cyrus, TJ, Buffy, and Kira’s storylines will all ultimately overlap and come full circle, and I think that still has to be true in some capacity. Kira not only has to find resolution with TJ and Cyrus, but she still has to resolve things with Buffy - the person she really has a problem with. Buffy is, on some level, aware of the chemistry between TJ and Cyrus - and she is already upset with TJ for the events of costume day, based on what we have learned from Andi’s Texts. Buffy and Cyrus are “crush buddies”, and there’s a chance that Cyrus may play a part in Muffy getting back together - so it would make sense if Buffy were involved in the rest of the Tyrus plot as well. 

I’ve discussed the importance of the parallels between TJ and Kira’s storylines before. TJ was introduced to the show through Buffy’s basketball storyline, as a bad guy, with the purpose of ultimately becoming Cyrus’ love interest. Kira was introduced to the show through Buffy’s basketball storyline, as a bad guy, with the purpose of ultimately (eventually) pushing TJ and Cyrus together. 

Early in TJ’s character arc, he appeared to be putting on a “tough” front, and became more mean the more threatened he felt by Buffy’s skills. We saw him have moments of being normal like when he was outside of the record store, and was actually okay towards Buffy until he was reminded that he feels inferior to her. And we’ve seen the exact same thing happen with Kira’s character. She was fairly kind when Buffy first invited her to be a part of the team, but got a big head and ultimately felt inferior to Buffy - so she started to act out and put on a front. 

Because we have already seen a complete redemption arc with TJ’s character, I honestly don’t even think we need a full redemption arc with Kira’s character. I keep thinking about that line that Josh shared that says “Sometimes there’s a nice person inside trying to get out,” and trying to think of how it will relate to the show. Obviously I don’t know the exact plot point it will be used in, but I think that, thematically, it can apply to a lot of characters we see on the show, and their journeys. 

I think that when you apply that quote to both TJ and Kira’s storylines, it makes it feel almost more natural if Kira’s character isn’t fully redeemed by it. Have her apologize, yes. Make it clear that her character is interested in changing for the better - the same way we have seen TJ and Amber change for the better. But we don’t actually have to see those changes happen. I could easily see that line being in a conversation where TJ is trying to explain why he was trying to be friends with Kira, despite her doing terrible things. Or I could see that line being used in a conversation where Cyrus is trying to rationalize why he still cares about TJ, and why he ultimately sees that even Kira deserves a second chance. But the line is just one of those quotes from the show that can be applied to so many situations, universally, and I think no matter where it actually fits in - the themes apply to this particular storyline well. 

So yeah. I don’t think Kira’s redemption needs to be tied up with a bow. I don’t think it has to be perfect. I don’t think anyone should expect to get nearly as much depth to her redemption as we have seen with other characters. She needs to realize what she did was wrong, and make amends with the appropriate characters. But it’s not necessary for us to go on that full journey with her. Sometimes things are left open-ended, and sometimes that’s a good thing.

I think that when you apply that quote to both TJ and Kira’s storylines, it makes it feel almost more natural if Kira’s character isn’t fully redeemed by it. Have her apologize, yes. Make it clear that her character is interested in changing for the better - the same way we have seen TJ and Amber change for the better. But we don’t actually have to see those changes happen. I could easily see that line being in a conversation where TJ is trying to explain why he was trying to be friends with Kira, despite her doing terrible things. Or I could see that line being used in a conversation where Cyrus is trying to rationalize why he still cares about TJ, and why he ultimately sees that even Kira deserves a second chance. But the line is just one of those quotes from the show that can be applied to so many situations, universally, and I think no matter where it actually fits in - the themes apply to this particular storyline well. 

So yeah. I don’t think Kira’s redemption needs to be tied up with a bow. I don’t think it has to be perfect. I don’t think anyone should expect to get nearly as much depth to her redemption as we have seen with other characters. She needs to realize what she did was wrong, and make amends with the appropriate characters. But it’s not necessary for us to go on that full journey with her. Sometimes things are left open-ended, and sometimes that’s a good thing.
trail.content:
I really don’t know, and I haven’t put too much thought into Kira’s arc honestly, so this post might just be me rambling while I figure out my own thoughts on the matter. For some people, she will not be fully redeemed no matter what happens on the show. She came in swinging, and this show’s audience aren’t just going to let that go no matter how complex the redemption is. 

I’ve said all along that I think that Cyrus, TJ, Buffy, and Kira’s storylines will all ultimately overlap and come full circle, and I think that still has to be true in some capacity. Kira not only has to find resolution with TJ and Cyrus, but she still has to resolve things with Buffy - the person she really has a problem with. Buffy is, on some level, aware of the chemistry between TJ and Cyrus - and she is already upset with TJ for the events of costume day, based on what we have learned from Andi’s Texts. Buffy and Cyrus are “crush buddies”, and there’s a chance that Cyrus may play a part in Muffy getting back together - so it would make sense if Buffy were involved in the rest of the Tyrus plot as well. 

I’ve discussed the importance of the parallels between TJ and Kira’s storylines before. TJ was introduced to the show through Buffy’s basketball storyline, as a bad guy, with the purpose of ultimately becoming Cyrus’ love interest. Kira was introduced to the show through Buffy’s basketball storyline, as a bad guy, with the purpose of ultimately (eventually) pushing TJ and Cyrus together. 

Early in TJ’s character arc, he appeared to be putting on a “tough” front, and became more mean the more threatened he felt by Buffy’s skills. We saw him have moments of being normal like when he was outside of the record store, and was actually okay towards Buffy until he was reminded that he feels inferior to her. And we’ve seen the exact same thing happen with Kira’s character. She was fairly kind when Buffy first invited her to be a part of the team, but got a big head and ultimately felt inferior to Buffy - so she started to act out and put on a front. 

Because we have already seen a complete redemption arc with TJ’s character, I honestly don’t even think we need a full redemption arc with Kira’s character. I keep thinking about that line that Josh shared that says “Sometimes there’s a nice person inside trying to get out,” and trying to think of how it will relate to the show. Obviously I don’t know the exact plot point it will be used in, but I think that, thematically, it can apply to a lot of characters we see on the show, and their journeys. 

I think that when you apply that quote to both TJ and Kira’s storylines, it makes it feel almost more natural if Kira’s character isn’t fully redeemed by it. Have her apologize, yes. Make it clear that her character is interested in changing for the better - the same way we have seen TJ and Amber change for the better. But we don’t actually have to see those changes happen. I could easily see that line being in a conversation where TJ is trying to explain why he was trying to be friends with Kira, despite her doing terrible things. Or I could see that line being used in a conversation where Cyrus is trying to rationalize why he still cares about TJ, and why he ultimately sees that even Kira deserves a second chance. But the line is just one of those quotes from the show that can be applied to so many situations, universally, and I think no matter where it actually fits in - the themes apply to this particular storyline well. 

So yeah. I don’t think Kira’s redemption needs to be tied up with a bow. I don’t think it has to be perfect. I don’t think anyone should expect to get nearly as much depth to her redemption as we have seen with other characters. She needs to realize what she did was wrong, and make amends with the appropriate characters. But it’s not necessary for us to go on that full journey with her. Sometimes things are left open-ended, and sometimes that’s a good thing.
